bibl.title: Letter from Arthur C. Jacobson to Philip Showalter Hench, March 25, 1949

div1.p: Jacobson writes that he would be delighted to receive photographs of Reed's Brooklyn Hospital diplomas for inclusion in an article and in an exhibit at the hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Arthur C. Jacobson to Philip Showalter Hench, March 25, 1949
div1.opener:
ARTHUR C. JACOBSON, M. D.
95 PIERREPONT STREET
BROOKLYN 2, N. Y.
March 25, 1949
Philip S. Hench, M. D.,
The Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Doctor deVeer, editor of the Brooklyn Hospital
Journal, in the next issue of which my Walter Reed article will
appear, will be delighted if photographic copies of Doctor Reed's
Brooklyn Hospital diplomas can be presented by you for inclusion
in my article and for placing in the permanent Reed exhibition at
the Hospital, with fervent acknowledgment of indebtedness to you.
This will forever settle the question as to whether Reed's intern-
ship in a Brooklyn hospital is always to mean, seemingly, just the
Kings County Hospital, as the historians usually, and erroneously,
of course, record the matter. This aside from the great pride
taken in the mere fact of Reed's internship at the Brooklyn Hospital
-- evidenced by the exhibition mentioned and in other ways.

I assure you that the discovery that the diplomas
were in existence thrilled Doctor Maynard and Doctor deVeer.

I feel myself that the reproduction of the diplomas
would be a justification for “dancing in the streets.” Certainly
it would lend a distinction to my paper which it otherwise would
not have.
We and the presses await your kind consideration.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Arthur C. Jacobson ACJ/h
